searchDocs.title: Starting the mina-archive container‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Mainnet Archive Node on Docker
searchDocs.content: docker run --name mina-archive -p 3086:3086 -v /tmp/archive:/data --entrypoint /bin/bash -it 154109f4622a

searchDocs.title: Running mina-archive‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Mainnet Archive Node on Docker
searchDocs.content: First check the IP adress of the docker container running postgres : 172.17.0.3  $ docker exec -it postgres bash root@f4f526a38062:/## ifconfig eth0: flags=4163<UP,BROADCAST,RUNNING,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 inet 172.17.0.3 netmask 255.255.0.0 broadcast 172.17.255.255 ether 02:42:ac:11:00:03 txqueuelen 0 (Ethernet) RX packets 145546 bytes 36562420 (34.8 MiB) RX errors 0 dropped 0 overruns 0 frame 0 TX packets 149990 bytes 319049761 (304.2 MiB) TX errors 0 dropped 0 overruns 0 carrier 0 collisions 0 lo: flags=73<UP,LOOPBACK,RUNNING> mtu 65536 inet 127.0.0.1 netmask 255.0.0.0 loop txqueuelen 1000 (Local Loopback) RX packets 0 bytes 0 (0.0 B) RX errors 0 dropped 0 overruns 0 frame 0 TX packets 0 bytes 0 (0.0 B) TX errors 0 dropped 0 overruns 0 carrier 0 collisions 0   Then run an interactive bash shell to the mina-archive container and run the mina-archive process :  $ docker exec -it mina-archive bash root@69c535e2f0b6:/## mina-archive run --postgres-uri postgres://postgres@172.17.0.3:5432/archive_balances_migrated --server-port 3086   SUCCESS You are all done !! You can get the last block indexed from the database by entering an interactive bash session to the postgrescontainer : $ docker exec -it postgres bash root@f4f526a38062:/## psql -U postgres -d archive_balances_migrated psql (16.2 (Debian 16.2-1.pgdg120+2)) Type "help" for help. archive_balances_migrated=## SELECT TO_CHAR(TO_TIMESTAMP(timestamp / 1000), 'YYYY-MM-DD HH24:MI:SS') AS utc_time, height, global_slot from blocks order by timestamp desc limit 1; utc_time | height | global_slot ---------------------+--------+------------- 2024-03-21 14:24:00 | 339249 | 528288 (1 row)

searchDocs.title: Catchup missing blocks‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Mainnet Archive Node on Docker
searchDocs.content: In order to catchup missing block, we will use a shell script available here : https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/blob/develop/scripts/archive/download-missing-blocks.sh  Script execution The script execution requires some tools from the mina-archive package. Notably : mina-missing-blocks-auditormina-archive-blocks  It means that the script can only be executed from the mina-archive docker container. So we copy the script to the mina-archive container :  docker cp download-missing-blocks.sh mina-archive:/   PROBLEM Now the big problem when running the script from the mina-archive docker container is that it tries to connect to the archive database but failed to do so due to docker network isolation :-( psql -h localhost -p 5432 -U postgres -d archive_balances_migrated FAILS  SOLUTION Use Docker Postgresql network ip address root@69c535e2f0b6:/## export PGPASSWORD=postgres root@69c535e2f0b6:/## ./download-missing-blocks.sh -n mainnet -a postgres://postgres@172.17.0.3:5432/archive_balances_migrated

searchDocs.title: USEFUL COMMANDS‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Mainnet Archive Node on Docker

searchDocs.title: List running docker containers‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Mainnet Archive Node on Docker
searchDocs.content: docker ps

searchDocs.title: Docker container logs‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Mainnet Archive Node on Docker
searchDocs.content: docker logs mina

searchDocs.title: Launch interactive shell session‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Mainnet Archive Node on Docker
searchDocs.content: POSTGRES Container‚Äã  docker exec -it postgres bash   Mina Container‚Äã  docker exec -it mina bash   Mina Archive Container‚Äã  docker exec -it mina-archive bash   Copy a local file to a container‚Äã  docker cp mainnet-archive-dump-2024-03-28_0001.sql postgres:/mainnet-archive-dump-2024-03-28_0001.sql docker cp download-missing-blocks.sh mina-archive:/   Running Mina Archive Container‚Äã  docker run --name mina-archive -p 3086:3086 -v /tmp/archive:/data --entrypoint /bin/bash -it 154109f4622a   remarque We forward port 3086 in order for the mina daemon to be able to connect to the mina-archive process. We also map /tmp/archive to /data The archive process will be launched manually from within the container (not ideal but more control over)  Running the postgres container‚Äã  docker run --name postgres -p 5432:5432 -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=postgres -d postgres

searchDocs.title: Official documentation‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: Official documentation to run a berkeley node is available here (latest Berkeley release on Feb, 18th 2024):  https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/releases/tag/2.0.0berkeley_rc1  Some additional information about running a mina node with docker is available here (may not be up to date and may concern mainnet, devnet and not Berkeley but a source of inspiration anyway) :  Additional Documentation Staketab documentationhttps://minanode.staketab.com/english/node-launch-options/running-mina-with-dockerOfficial mina testnet documentationhttps://docs.minaprotocol.com/node-operators/connecting-to-devnetOfficial mina mainnet documentationhttps://docs.minaprotocol.com/node-operators/connecting-to-the-network#docker

searchDocs.title: Docker images‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: Mina docker images are available on Docker Hub :  https://hub.docker.com/r/minaprotocol/mina-daemon/tags  For instance, the latest Berkeley RC1 release for Ubuntu Focal :  Links to Google Cloud images are also available in the Github release note : https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/releases/tag/2.0.0berkeley_rc1 Every docker image is built for each of the supported platforms. To select the base docker image, replace CODENAME with the codename appropriate for your machine (focal, buster, or bullseye): Mina Daemon: gcr.io/o1labs-192920/mina-daemon:2.0.0berkeley-rc1-1551e2f-CODENAME-berkeleyMina Archive: gcr.io/o1labs-192920/mina-archive:2.0.0berkeley-rc1-1551e2f-CODENAME So if you want to download the FOCAL latest release you can docker pull the following : https://gcr.io/o1labs-192920/mina-daemon:2.0.0berkeley-rc1-1551e2f-focal-berkeley

searchDocs.title: Usefull Docker CLI‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions

searchDocs.title: List available images‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: $ docker images

searchDocs.title: List docker container‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: There are 2 ways you can list running docker containers :  $ docker container ls   or  $ docker ps   There are 2 ways you can list all containers :  $ docker container ls -a   or  $ docker ps -a

searchDocs.title: Stop a running container‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: $ docker stop <container_name_or_id>

searchDocs.title: Start a container‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: $ docker start <container_name_or_id>

searchDocs.title: Remove a docker container‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: You can remove a Docker container :  $ docker rm <container_name_or_id>

searchDocs.title: Reattach a detach container‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: You can detach a container to let it run in the background by using CTRL+p CTRL+q. You may want to reattach a detached container. That can be achieved by :  $ docker attach <container_name_or_id>

searchDocs.title: Removing all stopped containers‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: The docker container prune command is used to remove all stopped containers from your Docker environment. It's a convenient way to clean up your system by removing containers that are no longer in use  $ docker container prune

searchDocs.title: Overriding Container entrypoint‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Frequently Ask Questions
searchDocs.content: Overriding the default container entrypoint can be really usefull to debug. We used this in the "Running a node on Mina berkeley with docker documentation" to access the container through an interactive shell that allowed us to generate all keys before launching the mina dameon (that failed without this).  For this, you will use the --entrypoint Docker command line parameter allowing you to specify to launch a bash shell for instance  Exemple $ docker run --name mina -p 9302:8302 -p 127.0.0.1:3085:3085 \ --mount "type=bind,source=$(pwd)/keys,dst=/root/keys" \ --mount "type=bind,source=$(pwd)/config,dst=/root/.mina-config" \ --env MINA_LIBP2P_PASS='pass' \ --env MINA_PRIVKEY_PASS='pass' \ --env UPTIME_PRIVKEY_PASS='pass' \ --entrypoint /bin/bash -it 353043fd4878

searchDocs.title: Running Mina Berkeley (the easiest way .. I found)
STEP 1 - Pull latest docker image‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Berkeley (the easiest way .. I found)
searchDocs.content: $ docker pull gcr.io/o1labs-192920/mina-daemon:2.0.0berkeley-rc1-1551e2f-focal-berkeley $ docker images REPOSITORY TAG IMAGE ID CREATED SIZE minaprotocol/mina-daemon 2.0.0berkeley-rc1-1551e2f-focal-berkeley 353043fd4878 2 weeks ago 2.41GB

searchDocs.title: STEP 2 - Create your keys and config directories on the host‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Berkeley (the easiest way .. I found)
searchDocs.content: $ mkdir keys $ mkdir config

searchDocs.title: STEP 3 - Getting an interactive bash session to the container‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Berkeley (the easiest way .. I found)
searchDocs.content: $ docker run --name mina -p 9302:8302 -p 127.0.0.1:3085:3085 --mount "type=bind,source=$(pwd)/keys,dst=/root/keys" --mount "type=bind,source=$(pwd)/config,dst=/root/.mina-config" --env MINA_LIBP2P_PASS='pass' --env MINA_PRIVKEY_PASS='pass' --env UPTIME_PRIVKEY_PASS='pass' --entrypoint /bin/bash -it 353043fd4878   Map keys and config directory from the host to the target container.Set your env variables MINA_LIBP2P_PASS, MINA_PRIVKEY_PASS (optionnal if you want to run a bloc producer) and UPTIME_PRIVKEY_PASS (not required/useless on berkeley)  353043fd4878 is your image id.

searchDocs.title: STEP 4 - Generating libp2p keypair‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Berkeley (the easiest way .. I found)
searchDocs.content: Once inside your container, you now have access to the shell. We'll use this to generate the libp2p key pair inside the /root/keys directory :  root@09437a971acb:~# mina libp2p generate-keypair -privkey-path /root/keys/libp2p Password for new private key file: Again to confirm: libp2p keypair: CAESQFGW4XhXBHPsGf...   Put the same password as the one you specify above for MINA_LIBP2P_PASS environment variable

searchDocs.title: STEP 5 - Generating BP keys‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Berkeley (the easiest way .. I found)
searchDocs.content: Then we'll generate the BP key (if needed) :  root@b8244db5dff8:~# mina-generate-keypair --privkey-path /root/keys/my-wallet Password for new private key file: Again to confirm: Keypair generated Public key: B62... Raw public key: 63B...   Put the same password as the one you specify above for MINA_PRIVKEY_PASS environment variable

searchDocs.title: STEP 6 - Launch Mina Daemon‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Running Mina Berkeley (the easiest way .. I found)
searchDocs.content: root@b8244db5dff8:~# mina daemon --peer-list-url https://storage.googleapis.com/seed-lists/berkeley_seeds.txt --libp2p-keypair ~/keys/libp2p --block-producer-key /root/keys/my-wallet --insecure-rest-server --open-limited-graphql-port --limited-graphql-port 3095 --file-log-level Debug -log-level Info   Once inside the container, pressing Ctrl + p, Ctrl + q will detach you from the container's console and leave the container running in the background.  You'll be able to reattach to you running mina container using :  $ docker attach mina   Launch intercative shell session again and check mina daemon status  You can launch an additionnal interactive session again to interact with mina daemon if needed :  $ docker exec -it mina /bin/bash   Then you can get the status of you mina daemon and guess what ? It is synced !!  root@156a3593fdf3:~# mina client status Mina daemon status ----------------------------------- Global number of accounts: 8181 Block height: 4285 Max observed block height: 4285 Max observed unvalidated block height: 4285 Local uptime: 26m32s Ledger Merkle root: jwi4sfjSY6JYKrjaL2wUUhYb6t7Ra5p5JhiMdznNFxbSPFZoN4W Protocol state hash: 3NLwovdQsqLfz8qHFrqbuLx7u4KccdbD94S65pKrw6tVVgHWkbkb Chain id: fd7d111973bf5a9e3e87384f560fdead2f272589ca00b6d9e357fca9839631da Git SHA-1: 1551e2faaa246c01636908aabe5f7981715a10f4 Configuration directory: /root/.mina-config Peers: 14 User_commands sent: 0 SNARK worker: None SNARK work fee: 100000000 Sync status: Synced Catchup status: To build breadcrumb: 0 To initial validate: 0 Finished: 293 To download: 0 Waiting for parent to finish: 0 To verify: 0 Block producers running: 1 (B62qmo7WKXRS3NNC7XNjZ15XDVD2doVgEoXKW4ELeE4SFDACzSm8vT7) Coinbase receiver: Block producer Best tip consensus time: epoch=1, slot=359 Best tip global slot (across all hard-forks): 7499 Next block will be produced in: None this epoch‚Ä¶ checking at in 14.125d (Generated from consensus at slot: 6970 slot-since-genesis: 6970) Consensus time now: epoch=1, slot=359 Consensus mechanism: proof_of_stake Consensus configuration: Delta: 0 k: 290 Slots per epoch: 7140 Slot duration: 3m Epoch duration: 14d21h Chain start timestamp: 2024-02-02 14:01:01.000000Z Acceptable network delay: 3m Addresses and ports: External IP: 0.0.0.0 Bind IP: 0.0.0.0 Libp2p PeerID: 12D3KooWE1tZXChc9c9ZbgwMgVVnmjqio49KKoZvEjeyaAEAWkYH Libp2p port: 8302 Client port: 8301 Metrics: block_production_delay: 7 (0 0 0 0 0 0 0) transaction_pool_diff_received: 48 transaction_pool_diff_broadcasted: 0 transactions_added_to_pool: 24 transaction_pool_size: 6 snark_pool_diff_received: 41 snark_pool_diff_broadcasted: 0 pending_snark_work: 0 snark_pool_size: 18

searchDocs.title: The tg_logbot.sh script‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Purpose
searchDocs.content: $ vim tg_logbot.sh   #!/bin/bash CHATID="0123456789" KEY="`YOUR_BOT_TOKEN`" TIME="10" URL="https://api.telegram.org/bot$KEY/sendMessage" while IFS= read -r line; do line=`echo "$line" | sed -e 's/\"//g'` line=`echo "$line" | sed -e 's/\[//g'` echo "$line" line=`echo "$line" | sed -e 's/\]//g'` echo "$line" line=`echo "$line" | sed -e 's/_/\\\_/g'` echo "$line" line=`echo "$line" | sed -e 's/\*//g'` echo send new line as msg: "$line" curl -s --max-time $TIME -d "chat_id=$CHATID&disable_web_page_preview=1&parse_mode=markdown" --data-urlencode "text=$line" $URL >/dev/null done   You will have to replace the CHATID and KEY values with your own ones.  Once saved, make the script executable :  $ chmod +x tg_logbot.sh   And once again, that is ALL !! You can now try to pipe, tail, cat whatever your want to the shell script which will handle its transfer to our chatbot !!

searchDocs.title: get_payouts.sh‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Purpose
searchDocs.content: The following script needs to be adapted to your configuration. In the example below, it assumes that :  ~/mina_scripts/payout/mina-pool-payout is the path to the mina_pool_payout script~/mina_scripts/payout.log will get the formatted payouts resulting from the payout script execution  $ vim get_payouts.sh   #!/bin/bash if [[ ( $@ == "--help") || $@ == "-h" ]] then echo "Usage: $0 [starting block] [end block] [epoch]" exit 0 fi sblock=$1 eblock=$2 epoch=$3 export POOL_MEMO="&lt;Bp_discord_id&gt;_epoch${epoch}_payout" nepoch=$epoch nsblock=$sblock neblock=$eblock if [ "$sblock" != "" ]; then sblock="-m=$sblock" fi if [ "$eblock" != "" ]; then eblock="-x=$eblock" fi if [ "$epoch" != "" ]; then epoch="-e=$epoch" sblock="" eblock="" fi debug=0 interval=3600 while true do # On lance le script de payout po="timeout 300 npm --prefix ~/mina_scripts/payout/mina-pool-payout/ run payout -- $sblock $eblock $epoch >/dev/null 2>&1" echo "$po" $po=$(eval "$po") # get last transaction file name fn=$(find ~/mina_scripts/payout/mina-pool-payout/src/data -name 'payout_transactions*' -type f -exec ls -t1 {} + 2>/dev/null | head -n 1) echo "$fn" echo "Le dernier fichier de payout est : $fn" # Extract the substring between the last '_' and the last '.' lastblock=$(echo "$fn" | grep -o '_[^_]*\.') # Remove the '_' at the beginning and the '.' at the end of the substring lastblock=${lastblock#_} lastblock=${lastblock%.} echo "lastblock: $lastblock" sblock="-m=$lastblock" epoch="" eblock="" echo -ne "\\n" # get the last generated payout transaction file json tr="find ~/mina_scripts/payout/mina-pool-payout/src/data -name 'payout_transactions*' -type f -exec ls -t1 {} + 2>/dev/null | head -n 1 | xargs cat | jq ." if [ "$debug" == "1" ]; then echo "$tr" fi #echo -ne "\\n" tr=$(eval "$tr") compte=$(echo "$tr" | jq '. | length') if [ "$debug" == "1" ]; then echo "$tr" fi echo "$compte payout √† effectuer" if [ "$compte" != "0" ]; then echo -e "Mina Epoch $nepoch$nsblock$neblock Payouts" >> ~/mina_scripts/payout.log fi #exit 0 for row in $(echo "${tr}" | jq -r '.[] | @base64'); do _jq() { echo ${row} | base64 --decode | jq -r ${1} } pk=$(_jq '.publicKey') amount=$(_jq '.amount') fee=$(_jq '.feeMina') memo=$(_jq '.memo') fee=0 amount=$(echo "scale=9 ;($amount + $fee)/1000000000" | bc) echo -e "$pk\\n$amount\\n$memo" >> ~/mina_scripts/payout.log done sleep $interval done   Once launched, this script will loop every hour, will check if some new payouts have been computed using the payout script from the last block it was launched before (so that only new payouts are returned and will be sent to the telegram bot).  remarque The script do not send the telegram message directly. Instead of that, it will add some entries to a payout.log file and this is exactly the only thing this script does !. The payout.log file will then be tailed in background to the tg_logbot.sh script so each time a new payout is added to payout.log it will be sent to the telegram bot.  Sample payout.log file Mina Epoch 70 Payouts B62... 2222.222222222 26192608020F76108A141C0C79366D9D B62... 1111.111111111 26192608020F76108A141C0C79366D9D B62... 33.333333333 Payout_Memo B62qiburnzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzmp7r7UN6X 3600.000000000 26192608020F76108A141C0C79366D9D

searchDocs.title: Using get_payouts.sh‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Purpose
searchDocs.content: The get_payouts.sh script can take either the starting epoch as argument or the start date and/or end date.  example $ ./get_payouts.sh "" "" "70"   remarque This script above will get payout from epoch 70 and then, as long as the script keeps running, all the payouts that will occur after the last block read. Note that if more than one block is produced between two runs in the loop, then all blocks will be taken into account in the computed results.  attention Ledgers (staking and next) have to be refreshed manually at the beginning of each new epoch (see Mina Pool Payout script documentation).  In order for the script to run in the backbround you can either use nohup along with & such as  $ nohup ./get_payouts.sh "" "" "70" &   Or my prefered method, launch the same in a screen session :  $ screen -S payout $ ./get_payouts.sh "" "" "70"   Then safely detach the screen session with CTRL+A+D. You can easily reattach the screen session with screen -R uptime thereafter.  Reminder Remember that the script only adds payout in a formatted way to the payout.log file and that it does not send anything to telegram.

searchDocs.title: Sending generated output to telegram‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Purpose
searchDocs.content: The last step, once the get_payouts.sh script runs in the background is to tail in another screen or background process the content of the payout.log file to the tg_logbot.sh script that will send our payout messages to our telegram bot private channel.  For this, as usual, you can either use nohup along with & such as  $ nohup tail -f payout.log | ./tg_logbot.sh &   or a new screen session :  $ screen -S payout_log $ tail -f payout.log | ./tg_logbot.sh   You're done !! Finally, once both the payout script and the tail of payout.log generated file will be in place, you will receive due payouts right in your telegram bot chat.

searchDocs.title: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
Create a telegram bot‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
searchDocs.content: The process to create a telegram bot is really straightforward and can be achieved in 6 easy steps.

searchDocs.title: Step 1. Open the telegram app‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
searchDocs.content: Open your telegram app on either your mobile phone or your computer

searchDocs.title: Step 2. Connect to Bot Father‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
searchDocs.content: BotFather is a bot/special user created by Telegram that allows you to create and manage your own bots. To connect to BotFather, search for "@BotFather" in the Telegram app and click on the result to start a conversation.

searchDocs.title: Step 3. Select the New Bot option‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
searchDocs.content: In the conversation with BotFather, select the "New Bot" option to start creating your new bot or simple type /newbot in the message panel. BotFather will guide you through the rest of the process.

searchDocs.title: Step 4. Add a bot friendly name and username‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
searchDocs.content: Next, BotFather will ask you to provide a name for your bot. Choose a name that accurately reflects the purpose of your bot and is easy to remember.  Lastly, BotFather will ask you to choose a username for your bot. This username will be used to create a unique URL that people can use to access your bot. Choose a username that is easy to remember and related to your bot's purpose.

searchDocs.title: Step 5. Test your bot token‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
searchDocs.content: Finally, your bot is created !    After obtaining your token, try pasting this URL into your browser:  https://api.telegram.org/bot`YOUR_BOT_TOKEN`/getMe  You'll get the information for your newly created bot :  { "ok": true, "result": { "id": **********, "is_bot": true, "first_name": "My First Bot", "username": "my_first_mina_bot", "can_join_groups": true, "can_read_all_group_messages": false, "supports_inline_queries": false } }

searchDocs.title: Step 6. Initiate a chat with your bot and get the ChatId‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
searchDocs.content: Last step consists of initiating a private chat with your bot so we can get a chatId we will adress to send message to. Just open a chat with your bot and click on Start  	  Then finally head over  https://api.telegram.org/bot`YOUR_BOT_TOKEN`/getUpdates  which should return something similar to :  { "ok": true, "result": [ { "update_id": 999999999, "message": { "message_id": 1, "from": { "id": 0123456789, "is_bot": false, "first_name": "chatfn", "username": "chatun", "language_code": "en" }, "chat": { "id": 0123456789, "first_name": "chatfn", "username": "chatun", "type": "private" }, "date": 1707867545, "text": "/start", "entities": [ { "offset": 0, "length": 6, "type": "bot_command" } ] } } ] }   And get your chat id here 0123456789 (example value)  And that's it! With these six easy steps, you can create your very own Telegram bot. Once you've created your bot, you can start adding features and programming it to do all sorts of fun and useful things.  More Information Telegram provides a detailed tutorial on bot create here : https://core.telegram.org/bots/tutorial  Summary Now you have your bot token and your chatId. These are the only two information you need to communicate with your bot from any program.

searchDocs.title: Use your Telegram bot‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Why do you need a telegram bot ?
searchDocs.content: Now that we have our bot ready, we will use it to send some information originating from our node. In principle, you'll find it extremely simple.  Now, let's try something !!  Example 1- Connect to your node 2- Type the following in your interactive Shell : $ curl -d "chat_id=0123456789&disable_web_page_preview=1&parse_mode=markdown" --data-urlencode "text=Hello" https://api.telegram.org/bot`YOUR_BOT_TOKEN`/sendMessage You will get the following response from telegram : { "ok": true, "result": { "message_id": 3, "from": { "id": **********, "is_bot": true, "first_name": "My First Bot", "username": "my_first_mina_bot" }, "chat": { "id": 0123456789, "first_name": "chatfn", "username": "chatun", "type": "private" }, "date": 1707869569, "text": "Hello" } } And in your telegram private chat with your bot : ...So .... Cool !!!  remarque Every examples that will follow here are based on exactly the same operating principle. A program sends text via the Telegram APIs to our private chat with our bot. There's a lot more you can do with a bot that won't be covered here (questions, answers, interactivity, commands...).

searchDocs.title: What the bot can do‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Wallets in Telegram: create, encrypt & store, list, set default, reveal private key (with password), delegate stake, send payments, tip users, claim faucets, and run rain distributionsAddress & Validator Watching: get alerts on transactions, delegations, zkApps, token transfers; get notified on validator block production (canonical/orphan)On-chain Insights: get current block/epoch, resolve truncated addresses, validator stats, payout estimations per epochLeaderboards & Referrals: tips leaderboard and referrer leaderboard (public groups) + personal referral settingsMini-Games (public groups): /dice_roll and /guess (configurable tries & bet multiplier) with token stakesMina Price Chart: view a quick price chart via /pcFaucet Claim: get 5 test MINA on zeko_testnet or devnet via /faucetMulti-Network: mainnet | devnet | zeko_testnet (defaults indicated per command)  üß≠ Convention Angled brackets <...> = requiredSquare brackets [...] = optional_italics_ = default valueAliases are shown with a pipe: /command | /alias

searchDocs.title: Security & Custody Model‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Your private key is securely encrypted and stored on our servers using modern cryptography (AES-GCM) and a password known only to you. We never store your password, and it is never logged or sent anywhere beyond the secure Telegram channel you use to communicate with the bot.  When you perform an action that requires your private key (such as signing a transaction), the bot temporarily decrypts your key in memory only, using your password, to sign the requested operation. Immediately afterward, the key and decrypted data are permanently wiped from memory.  Even in the event of a data breach or database leak, your encrypted keys would remain mathematically unusable without your password.  The bot server itself is not directly reachable from the Internet ‚Äî it communicates exclusively through Telegram‚Äôs secure API channels.

searchDocs.title: What This Means‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Only you can use your key ‚Äî nobody else knows your password.Your key never leaves the secure server environment in decrypted form.The server cannot access or recover your key without your password.The system provides a level of protection comparable to local non-custodial wallets.  However, because decryption and signing occur on the server (under your explicit command), this wallet is not strictly ‚Äúnon-custodial‚Äù in the pure cryptographic sense. It is best described as a secure custodial wallet with zero-knowledge encryption ‚Äî combining strong security, simplicity, and user control.  Summary‚Äã  Aspect	DescriptionEncryption	AES-GCM with Argon2 password-derived key Password	Known only by the user, never stored or logged Decryption	Performed temporarily in memory for each operation Exposure	No inbound ports, Telegram API only Custody classification	Secure custodial (zero-knowledge) External attack surface	Extremely low

searchDocs.title: How to Start‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Getting started with the Mina Wallet Bot only takes a few minutes. Follow these 4 simple steps:

searchDocs.title: 1. Start a private chat with the bot‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Open this link and press Start: üëâ https://t.me/mina_monitor_bot  All sensitive actions (password, private key, signing) must be done in private DM for security.  Upon start, you will be asked if you want to create your wallet (you can delay your wallet creation and create it later (See 2).

searchDocs.title: 2. Create your first Mina wallet‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: In DM, type:  /create_wallet   After having accepted the disclaimer :    You will be asked to choose a password. This password encrypts your private key and is never stored anywhere.    After confirming, the bot creates your wallet and displays your public address.

searchDocs.title: 3. Claim a faucet (testnet only)‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: To get 5 test MINA on devnet or zeko_testnet, type:  /faucet devnet   or  /faucet zeko_testnet     You can use these funds to test tips, games, or payments safely.

searchDocs.title: 4. Send your first MINA (tip someone)‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Once you have testnet MINA, try sending some:  /tip B62qqxVafmoBataYLwazvkWEFKWsjPG8ajYEG9aSUpVkpos3XCWYbzw 1 0.01 zeko_testnet   or  /tip @telegram_username 1 0.01 zeko_testnet   The bot will ask for your password so it can decrypt your key in memory and sign the transaction.      You‚Äôre ready! You now have a working wallet, funds, and the ability to send and receive MINA or use all the bot‚Äôs advanced features.

searchDocs.title: Private Chat Commands‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: DM the bot to manage your wallets, watchlists, referrals, and alerts. Some commands have aliases for convenience.

searchDocs.title: Watchlists‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Watch a wallet address‚Äã  /watch | /wa <address> <label> Receive alerts for:  Payment in/outDelegation in/outzkAppsToken transfers  Example  /watch B62qrmRJ...C7agyYEZ MY_WALLET   Unwatch a wallet address‚Äã  /unwatch | /ua <address>  Watch a validator (block producer)‚Äã  /watch_validator | /wv <validator_address> <label>  Example  /watch_validator B62qpsyB...a9fFnWr Naamah   Unwatch a validator‚Äã  /unwatch_validator | /uv <validator_address>  Rename any watched entry (address or validator)‚Äã  /rename | /rn <address_or_validator> <label>  List all watched items‚Äã  /list | /l

searchDocs.title: Wallet Management‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Create wallet‚Äã  /create_wallet | /cw Prompts for a password, creates a keypair, encrypts the private key, and stores it securely.  Delete a wallet‚Äã  /user_delete_wallet Removes a Mina wallet from your list.  List your wallets‚Äã  /list_wallets | /lw Shows your public addresses. The default one is marked.  Set default wallet‚Äã  /set_default | /sd <wallet_address> Sets <wallet_address> as your default for tip/send operations.  Show private key‚Äã  /show_private_key | /spk [<public_key>] Reveals your private key after password verification. If you have multiple wallets, specify the public key.  Delegate stake (from your Telegram wallets)‚Äã  /delegate Interactive flow to delegate the stake of your Telegram-managed wallets.

searchDocs.title: Transfers & Tools (DM)‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Unless stated otherwise, default network is mainnet. You can override with devnet or zeko_testnet when supported.  Build & send with Auro (deeplink)‚Äã  /send <recipient_address> <amount> <fee> [memo] [network_id (**mainnet**|devnet|zeko_testnet)] Builds a payment link and opens Auro for signing/broadcast.  Tip from your wallet(s)‚Äã  Single-wallet flow: /tip <to> <amount> <fee> [memo] [*mainnet*|devnet|zeko_testnet]Multi-wallet flow (explicit source): /tip <from> <to> <amount> <fee> [memo] [*mainnet*|devnet|zeko_testnet]  to can be a B62 address or an @username (if they have a registered wallet).  Faucet (DM)‚Äã  /faucet [devnet|zeko_testnet] Claim a 5 MINA faucet on zeko_testnet or mina devnet (limited to 1 faucet per user).  Check balances‚Äã  Address: /balance | /b <address> [*mainnet*|devnet|zeko_testnet]All wallets of an @username: /balance | /b <@username> [*mainnet*|devnet|zeko_testnet]  Price chart‚Äã  /pc ‚Äì Displays Mina price chart.

searchDocs.title: Alerts & Stats (DM)‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Empty coinbase alert‚Äã  /alert_coinbase | /ac on|off Enable/disable global alerts when a block is produced with empty coinbase.  Validator stats‚Äã  /validator_stats | /vs [epoch] [validator]  No args ‚Üí show global stats (current epoch)With epoch/validator ‚Üí filter results  Resolve truncated address‚Äã  /get_full_address | /gf <short_address> Resolve B62...abcd ‚Üí full address  Block & epoch info‚Äã  Current block/epoch/slot: /get_block | /gbSpecific block: /get_block | /gb <height>  Show all blocks (live scroll)‚Äã  /show_all ‚Äì Live stream of produced blocks (use with care).

searchDocs.title: Referrals (DM)‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Show / update my referral‚Äã  /my_referral | /mr View or set your referrer code/username to participate in referral leaderboards.

searchDocs.title: Help & Menus (DM)‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Help‚Äã  /help ‚Äì Displays this help menu with all available commands.  Menu‚Äã  /menu ‚Äì Opens the interactive button-based menu for quick access to main bot functions.  You can trigger the menu at any time to quickly access the main sections of the bot such as wallet management, delegation, epoch info, or watchlist.    The menu allows users to easily navigate core features without remembering all command names. Each button corresponds to one of the major functional areas: ‚ùì Help ‚Äî Displays the list of all available commandsüì¶ Epoch ‚Äî Shows current epoch, slot, and block informationüóíÔ∏è Watchlist ‚Äî Manage your watched addresses and validatorsüí∞ Wallets ‚Äî Manage your Mina wallets (create, list, set default, etc.)üß≠ Delegate ‚Äî Delegate your stake to a validatorüÜï Wallet ‚Äî Quickly create a new Mina wallet

searchDocs.title: Public Group Commands‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Use these in public groups. Some actions (like rain or games) will require a DM confirmation (password) by involved players for security.

searchDocs.title: Info & Tools‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: /pc ‚Äî Show Mina Price Chart/get_block | /gb ‚Äî Current block height, epoch, slot/get_block | /gb <height> ‚Äî Show block info for <height>/help ‚Äî Quick help/menu ‚Äî Open quick access menu/balance | /b <address> ‚Äî Show balance in MINA/balance | /b <@username> [mainnet|devnet|zeko_testnet] ‚Äî Show all balances of an @user (default: mainnet)/faucet [devnet|zeko_testnet] ‚Äî Claim a 5 MINA faucet on zeko_testnet or mina devnet (1 faucet per user)

searchDocs.title: Wallet Actions in Group‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: These actions will ask the sender to confirm in DM (password) if they require signing.  Create wallet (guided in DM)‚Äã  /create_wallet | /cw Starts wallet creation flow (continues in DM).  Tip a user‚Äã  /tip @telegram_user <amount> [fee] [memo] [*mainnet*|devnet|zeko_testnet] Sends a tip from your default wallet. DM confirmation may be required.  Rain (random distribution)‚Äã  /rain <amount> <nb_users> [fee] [memo] [network_id (**mainnet**|devnet|zeko_testnet)] Randomly distribute <amount> among <nb_users> eligible members (must have a wallet & be in this group). Requires DM confirmation (password). Summary posted in group.

searchDocs.title: Leaderboards (Group)‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: /leaderboard | /lb [*mainnet*|devnet|zeko_testnet] [YYYY-MM-DD] [YYYY-MM-DD] Tip leaderboard over an optional date range and network./reflb Referrer leaderboard.

searchDocs.title: Mini-Games (Group)‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Players must have wallets & will confirm in DM before any transfer/signing. First, users may need to opt-in to games (e.g. via a private /game toggle if you keep that anti-spam switch).  IMPORTANT Games are only available on testnets/devnets.  Dice Roll‚Äã  /dice_roll @username <amount> [network_id (devnet|**zeko_testnet**)] Challenge another user to a dice roll. Highest roll wins the pot.  Bot DM flow: both players confirm with passwordOn success: winner receives <amount> from the loser (or split pot if you configured a pot logic)  Example  /dice_roll @alice 1   Guess My Number‚Äã  /guess @username <amount> [number_of_tries(_default: 5_)] [bet_multiplier(_default: 1_)] [network_id (devnet|**zeko_testnet**)] Challenge another player to guess a number between 1 and 100.  number_of_tries: how many guesses the opponent gets (default 5)bet_multiplier: if the opponent finds the number, they win multiplier √ó amount; if not, the starter wins 1 √ó amount  Examples  /guess @alice 2 /guess @alice 2 7 3 /guess @alice 2 7 3 zeko_testnet   The final DM result message includes the secret number for transparency.

searchDocs.title: Notes & Best Practices‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Mina Telegram Bot
searchDocs.content: Security first: The bot will always ask for your password in DM before any action requiring your private key.Networks: Many commands default to mainnet; specify devnet or zeko_testnet when needed.Aliases: Use the short forms (/wa, /wv, /uv, /rn, /lw, /sd, /spk, /vs, /gf, /gb, /ac, /lb) for faster typing.Gaming opt-in: If enabled in your deployment, users must first opt-in via a private /game toggle to avoid spam.Group eligibility (rain/games): Users must have a wallet registered and be present in the group.

searchDocs.title: get_uptime.sh‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Purpose
searchDocs.content: The script we will use is the following :  $ vim get_uptime.sh   #!/bin/bash while true do since="24 hours ago" && echo && echo "$(hostname) : Uptime service - sent : $(journalctl --user -u mina -S "$since" | grep 'Sent block with state' | wc -l), failed: $(journalctl --user -u mina -S "$since" | grep 'After 8 attempts, failed' | wc -l)" sleep 3600 done   Once launched, this script will loop every hour and return the number of successfull and failed uptime upload retrieved from mina logs.  Example Hostname : Uptime service - sent : 96, failed: 0

searchDocs.title: Using get_uptime.sh with tg_logbot.sh‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Purpose
searchDocs.content: In order to send the ouput of the script each time it runs (every hour) to telegram, we will do something as easy as pipe the output from get_uptime.sh to tg_logbot.sh  Example $ ./get_uptime.sh | ./tg_logbot.sh   In order for the script to run in the backbround you can either use nohup along with & such as  $ nohup ./get_uptime.sh | ./tg_logbot.sh &   Or my prefered method, launch the same in a screen session :  $ screen -S uptime $ ./get_uptime.sh | ./tg_logbot.sh   Then safely detach the screen session with CTRL+A+D. You can easily reattach the screen session with screen -R uptime thereafter.  You're done !! Finally, once run, you'll receive every hour right in your telegram chat window with your bot a message with your actual 24 hour uptime.  Uptime value The uptime retrieved from the script is the splipping 24 hours uptime. Its value should be 96 (1 upload every 15min, 4 uploads each hour, 4x24=96 uploads a day) which means that you did not miss any uptime upload to the server. Please note that when a block is produced, an additional entry in the logs is added that will count as a snark upload as well. It means that if you produced 3 blocks the last 24h, then your score will be 99 and not 96.

searchDocs.title: Qu'est-ce qu'un wallet non-custodial ?‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Wallets "Non custodial"
searchDocs.content: Par d√©finition, un wallet "non custodial" s'oppose √† un wallet "custodial" et repr√©sente un wallet dont vous poss√©dez la cl√© priv√©e et sur lequel vous et vous seul avez la maitrise.  L'achat de mina n√©cessite de se connecter √† une plateforme d'√©change qui permet d'√©changer une devise (Euro, USD, autre crypto, ..) contre des minas.  Une fois les minas en votre possession, ils sont disponibles via la plateforme d'√©change et vous pouvez √©ventuellement proc√©der √† des trades (short, long) sur vos token sur les paires d'√©changes disponibles sur la plateforme.  info Il n'existe quasiment aucune plateforme d'√©change aujourd'hui qui vous permette d'acc√©der √† votre cl√© priv√©e qui est du point de vue de la blockchain la seule preuve que vos token vous appartiennent. Au lieu de cela, les adresses de vos wallet sur les √©changes vous sont attribu√©s par la plateforme qui ne vous donne acc√®s la plupart du temps qu'√† la cl√© publique du wallet (qui vous permet de d√©poser des fonds) sans jamais vous donner acc√®s √† la cl√© priv√©e (qui vous permet d'op√©rer, de sortir des fonds, de contr√¥ler, ....) votre wallet.  CONCLUSION Vos tokens stock√©s sur un √©change ne vous appartiennent pas !!!  Les avantages de conserver ses token sur une plateforme d'√©change L'avantage de stocker sur une plateforme d'√©change (et il n'y en a qu'un !) est de pouvoir trader (=√©changer / acheter / vendre) rapidement vos token.  Les inconv√©nients de conserver ses tokens sur une plateforme d'√©change Il y a de nombreux d√©savantages √† laisser ses tokens sur une plateforme centralis√©e :  Le premier est que c'est en totale contradiction avec le principe m√™me de la blockchain qui est d'√™tre d√©centralis√©e.Le second inconv√©nient est que vous n'avez aucun contr√¥le en th√©orie sur vos fonds. Si la plateforme met la cl√© sous la porte, vous perdez alors 100% de vos investissements !!Le troisi√®me inconv√©nient concerne le staking. Le staking dans le contexte d'une blockchain bas√©e sur le Proof Of Stake (PoS) comme Mina consiste √† d√©l√©guer1 ses token √† un validateur2 de confiance afin de lui octroyer des chances suppl√©mentaires de produire des blocs3 g√©n√©rant des r√©compenses (coinbase4). Ces r√©compenses sont ensuite distribu√©es aux d√©l√©gateurs au prorata du nombre de mina d√©l√©gu√©s moins la commission prise par le validateur (En th√©orie entre 0% et 10%, la majorit√© appliquant un taux de 5%). Lorsque vos minas sont stock√©es sur une plateforme, dans le meilleur des cas, celle-ci propose leurs propres conditions de staking a des taux de commission √©lev√©s mais la plupart des plateformes ne propose tout simplement pas de staking, vous privant alors d'une source de revenu passive loin d'√™tre n√©gligeable (entre 12% et 24% d'APR)Le quatri√®me inconv√©nient est qu'un wallet non custodial ne permet pas l'utilisation de ce wallet sur des applications sp√©cifiques de la blockchain (DApps ou zkApps5 dans le contexte Mina).  1 Staking Plus d'info sur le staking dans la section d√©di√©e. Cliquez ici : üîóStaking Guide  2 Validateur G√©n√©ralement, dans une blockchain bas√©e sur du Proof of Stake, un validateur est un participant √† la blockchain qui bloque un certain montant de token en garantie. Cette garantie sert de d√©p√¥t de s√©curit√© et garantit que les validateurs ont un int√©r√™t financier √† maintenir l'int√©grit√© du r√©seau. Dans le contexte de Mina, il est important de noter que les fonds mis en jeu pour le staking ne sont pas v√©rouill√©s Cela signifie que les fonds des d√©l√©gateurs utilis√©s pour le staking peuvent √™tre d√©plac√©s, re-d√©l√©gu√©s, un-d√©l√©gu√©s, transf√©r√©s, √©chang√©s, vendus librement √† tout moment.  3 Blocs Les validateurs se relaient pour cr√©er de nouveaux blocs et valider des transactions en fonction de la quantit√© de cryptomonnaie qu'ils ont mise en jeu (en propre ou via des d√©l√©gations). Plus un validateur a de cryptomonnaie en jeu (ou de token d√©l√©gu√©s) , plus il a de chances d'√™tre choisi pour cr√©er un nouveau bloc.  4 Coinbase Les validateurs sont r√©compens√©s par des cryptomonnaies suppl√©mentaires pour avoir cr√©√© et valid√© avec succ√®s des blocs. Le coinbase est une transaction sp√©ciale dans un bloc nouvellement cr√©√© qui contient la r√©compense due au validateur ayant produit le nouveau bloc. Actuellement la base de la r√©compense pour la production d'un bloc sur mina est des 720 minas, auquel s'ajoute 720 minas suppl√©mentaires (supercharged reward) si le slot de production a √©t√© gagn√© par une adresse non lock√©e.  5 zkApps

searchDocs.title: Auro Wallet‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Wallets "Non custodial"
searchDocs.content: site officiel : https://www.aurowallet.com/    Description (Site Web Officiel) Disponible sous la forme d'une extension de navigateur et d'une application mobile, Auro Wallet est disponible dans plusieurs langues, prend en charge parfaitement le protocole Mina et est enti√®rement open-source. Avec lui, vous pouvez facilement envoyer, recevoir ou staker vos MINA, et consulter votre historique de transactions √† tout moment. Il prend √©galement en charge l'envoi de transactions zkApp (lorque les apps seront disponibles sur le mainnet (ndlr))  Mon Avis  Les avantages de Auro Wallet :  Disponible sous la forme d'une application Android ou iOSDisponible sous la forme d'une extension de navigateur (Chrome, Edge, Firefox)Compatible Hardware Wallet LedgerPr√™t pour les zkAppsGestion de plusieurs WalletStaking inAppOpen source

searchDocs.title: Clorio Wallet‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Wallets "Non custodial"
searchDocs.content: site officiel : https://clor.io/    Description (Site Web Officiel) Clorio est un wallet open source pour le protocole Mina, √©crit en JavaScript. Avec Clorio, vous pouvez interagir avec la blockchain Mina en g√©n√©rant/utilisant votre cl√© priv√©e ou en utilisant le wallet mat√©riel Ledger. Le portefeuille Clorio ne transmet pas votre cl√© priv√©e en dehors de l'application client, toutes les transactions sont sign√©es localement ou sur votre appareil Ledger. Clorio est un wallet non-custodial, ce qui signifie que vous √™tes le seul responsable de la conservation s√©curis√©e de votre cl√© priv√©e. Vous √™tes essentiellement votre propre banque.  Mon Avis  Les avantages de Clorio :  Disponible en tant qu'application de bureau (windows, Mac OSX and Linux)Compatible pour Ledger hardware walletMulti-account, wallets managementEasy inApp stakingOpen source

searchDocs.title: Guide du staking‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Staking guide
searchDocs.content: La documentation officielle de Mina contient un guide tr√®s d√©taill√© sur le staking. Vous trouverez de nombreuses informations utiles sur le site web officiel de Mina et dans leur blog.  Si vous souhaitez simplement utiliser un wallet non custodial pour d√©l√©guer vos Mina √† un validateur tiers, suivez simplement les √©tapes simples d√©crites ici :  Installez un wallet Mina https://docs.minaprotocol.com/using-mina/install-a-wallet D√©l√©guer votre stake √† un validateur en utilisant votre portefeuille https://docs.minaprotocol.com/using-mina/how-to-delegate  Plus de d√©tails dans cet article de blog :  https://minaprotocol.com/blog/staking-rewards-on-mina Dans cet article de blog, vous apprendrez : Comment cr√©er une cl√©Comment choisir le pool de staking le plus appropri√© √† vos besoins en utilisant les explorateurs existants√Ä quoi vous attendre en termes de r√©compenses et de rendement annuel (APY) de votre producteur de blocs / validateur....  remarque Comme indiqu√© sur la page du blog : Apr√®s une r√©affectation, il y a une p√©riode de latence de 2 √† 4 semaines avant que votre nouvelle d√©l√©gation de mise ne prenne effet. Les paiements des r√©compenses de bloc se font hors cha√Æne, que le fournisseur de services de staking devrait vous envoyer. V√©rifiez avec chaque fournisseur/pool pour ses conditions de d√©l√©gation (frais, versement des r√©compenses, ..) Assurez-vous de faire vos propres recherches avant de choisir un pool de staking. Parmi les crit√®res importants √† consid√©rer : Performance du n≈ìud (cliquez sur chaque validateur dans cette liste pour voir leurs statistiques de performance.)Leur r√©activit√©, leur activit√© et leur r√©putation au sein de la communaut√©Leurs conditions (% de frais qu'ils facturent, fr√©quence d'envoi des r√©compenses, etc.) et leur historique de respect de ces conditions (peut √™tre v√©rifi√© en utilisant un explorateur de blocs (comme Mina Explorer, Minataur, Minascan) Si vous avez des questions sur les pools de mise en jeu, il y a un canal #staking-pool sur le serveur Discord de Mina.  info J'ai √©galement d√©velopp√© un calculateur de r√©compenses pour les d√©l√©gateurs / un simulateur de paiement / un outil de comparaison de la performance des producteurs de blocs disponible ici : https://mina.naamahdaemon.eu/payout-simulator Cela peut vous aider √† d√©terminer quel validateur peut vous offrir les meilleurs rendements. searchDocs.title: Welcome to Our Verified ZKApps Section!
searchDocs.content: Welcome to Our Verified ZKApps Section! In this section of our website, you'll find a lightly verified list of ZKApps that I have personally tested to ensure they are functional. Each application includes a quick user guide and direct links for easy access. While the verification process is minimal, focusing solely on basic functionality, you can still explore these ZKApps with confidence. This section is designed to provide you with practical insights and straightforward guidance on each application.

searchDocs.content: Depuis le site web original :  Description ID-Mask est une application qui permet de cr√©er des preuves √† divulgation nulle de connaissance (zero-knowledge proofs), permettant aux individus de v√©rifier des d√©clarations sur leur identit√© √† des tiers sans divulguer aucune information personnelle. Les preuves produites peuvent √™tre utilis√©es par d'autres parties qui les trouvent utiles, par exemple d'autres applications, des gouvernements, des DEX, etc.  ID-Mask permet √† n'importe qui de g√©n√©rer plusieurs types de preuves, fournies par des sources de confiance (la source de confiance support√©e sur le mainnet est l'application d'identit√© Smart-ID (voir ci-dessous).  Preuve d'√¢gePreuve de non-sanctionPreuve d'humain uniquePreuve de nationalit√©  Il est possible de simuler la v√©rification d'identit√© sur testnet afin d'avoir un aper√ßu de son fonctionnement.  remarque Comme je ne peux pas utiliser Smart-ID dans mon pays, je n'ai pas pu tester la g√©n√©ration de preuves sur le mainnet. √Ä la place, j'ai seulement effectu√© des tests sur le testnet en utilisant des donn√©es factices g√©n√©r√©es automatiquement.  Une fois la preuve g√©n√©r√©e, elle peut soit √™tre conserv√©e localement (preuve g√©n√©r√©e par le front-end) soit √™tre propag√©e on-chain ou dans Google ou Apple Wallet pour pouvoir √™tre pr√©sent√©e afin de prouver vos d√©clarations √† un tiers v√©rificateur √† tout moment.

searchDocs.pageTitle: ID-Mask
searchDocs.content: Comme indiqu√© ci-dessus, ID-Mask peut g√©n√©rer 4 cat√©gories de preuves :  Preuve d'√¢gePreuve de non-sanctionPreuve d'humain uniquePreuve de nationalit√©    Essayons avec la premi√®re : Preuve d'√¢ge  √âTAPE 1 - Obtenir des donn√©es factices‚Äã    √âTAPE 2 - Cr√©er la preuve‚Äã  Nous voulons prouver que nous avons plus de 8 ans    Si vous avez demand√© dans les param√®tres que votre portefeuille signe la preuve g√©n√©r√©e, alors votre portefeuille web extension devrait s'ouvrir et vous permettre de signer la demande.    √âTAPE 3 - Enregistrer la preuve g√©n√©r√©e‚Äã  Une fois la preuve g√©n√©r√©e, vous pouvez l'enregistrer pour une utilisation ult√©rieure par un v√©rificateur :  Dans un fichier JSONEn la mettant on-chainEn l'ajoutant √† votre Google ou Apple Wallet    Mettons notre preuve on-chain en cliquant sur Put on chain.    remarque Cela peut prendre un certain temps, soyez patient üòâ  Acceptez la transaction dans votre portefeuille    Une fois tout en ordre, vous remarquerez une popup vous informant que la transaction est maintenant on-chain.
